doc.title: 1st September - 5th September and beyond
doc.source_uri: 2025-08-28/European Week Ahead 1st September 5th September and beyond 1st September - 5th September and beyondEuropean Week Ahead 1_2025-08-28

passages.text: We focus on 12 previews, of which 4 appear on our Watch List.
This week, Coloplast is holding a CMD on 2 September.

We expect the September CMD to be an opportunity for strategic clarity, particularly around IU, with a potential exit from this segment well received by investors, in our view. Overall, we continue to view Coloplast as a high-

quality company with an impressive product portfolio and acknowledge that valuation is depressed relative to history, yet we believe uncertainty around leadership and mid- term targets remains an overhang. (Coloplast A/S: Q3 Preview: All eyes on September CMD, 1 July 2025)

Further out, ASM International is holding a CMD on 23 September. ASM guided 2027 at €4- 5bn at its last CMD. Since then, FX has devalued materially whilst the customer landscape has also shifted meaningfully. Updating for FX would suggest a new range along the lines of €3.5- 4.5bn. However, ASMI was assuming a WFE market of \(120bn o/w\) \(\) 50b\(was related to GAA. We currently expect WFE to be flatish in 2026 but see reasons for 2027 to be a growth year (\) 8\%), potentially growing towards\) 110bn. We estimate the main delta to ASM's previous expectations though is in the NAND market where ASMI has limited exposure. Thus a cut for a weaker WFE outlook could have limited impact on ASM. Given how many things can change between now and 2027, ASM may choose to only update for FX, in our view. We estimate the mix of revenues for ASM in 2025 to be roughly 40% leading edge, 20% lagging edge, \(< 20\%\) memory and 20% spares/services but this has fluctuated drastically between 2022- 2025. At the last CMD, ASM helpfully provided a SAM of \(\) 400m\(for the move from FinFET to GAA. In Outpacing the rest (3 June 2025), we estimated that ASM has captured 60%. We also estimated that a SAM for A14 vs N2 could be\) \ \(400m\) again (including backside power) - highlighting the continued growth from ALD and epitaxy. We also expect ASM to flag opportunities around molybdenum (although tangible wins are needed to reassure on growth here given competition), CFET (GAA stacked which could increase the SAM materially again), DRAM moving to 4f2 (we estimate could double ASM's DRAM TAM). We hope for some colour on 2026 but expect ASM to focus on these long- term drivers. (ASM International N.V.: Thoughts ahead of CMD, 21 August 2025)

\* This individual is a member of the Product Management Group and is not a Research Analyst Please see analyst certifications and important disclosures beginning on page 5. Completed: 28- Aug- 25, 12:06 GMT Released: 28- Aug- 25, 12:10 GMT Restricted - External

Fed put killed vol & promoted HF/systematic buying spree. Positioning higher in US, beware of Sep seasonality and pocket of froth. But still much dry powder to fuel BTD, melt- up & broadening if data hold. It less hot & France a reality- check for crowded domestics but political risk likely contained. (Who owns What: Fed put unleashed, 27 August 2025)

Overweight - The stock is expected to outperform the unweighted expected total return of the industry coverage universe over a 12- month investment horizon.
Equal Weight - The stock is expected to perform in line with the unweighted expected total return of the industry coverage universe over a 12- month investment horizon.
Underweight - The stock is expected to underperform the unweighted expected total return of the industry coverage universe over a 12- month investment horizon.
Positive - industry coverage universe fundamentals/valuations are improving.
Neutral - industry coverage universe fundamentals/valuations are steady, neither improving nor deteriorating.
Negative - industry coverage universe fundamentals/valuations are deteriorating.

*This is the closing price referenced in the publication, which may not be the last available closing price at the time of publication.
Historical stock prices and price targets may have been adjusted for stock splits and dividends.

**Valuation** **Methodology:** We value ASMl with a target 2027E P/E of c27x, which is a slight premium to its historical average and a material premium to peers. ASMl has historically traded at a premium to competitors, which we view as justified given its superior growth.

**Risks** **which** **May** **Impede** **the** **Achievement** **of** **the** **Barclays** **Research** **Valuation** **and** **Price** **Target:** Key risks to our investment thesis include 1) a slower-than-expected rebound in end-markets leading to a material increase/decrease in WFE spend and therefore demand for ASMl's tools, 2)slower-than-expected transitions to new nodes, and 3) slower and smaller market share gains across its key markets, such as in epitaxy.

Source: Bloomberg, Barclays Research
*This is the closing price referenced in the publication, which may not be the last available closing price at the time of publication.
Historical stock prices and price targets may have been adjusted for stock splits and dividends.

**Valuation** **Methodology:** We derive our PT by using a blended c.32x P/E and c.25x EV/EBITDA on FY25E, in line with the 10-year average premium to the sector. We sense check using DCF (WACC of 6.75% and TGR of 4%), which yields a similar valuation.

**Risks** **which** **May** **Impede** **the** **Achievement** **of** **the** **Barclays** **Research** **Valuation** **and** **Price** **Target:** Downside Risks - 1) Poor execution against the pipeline of new launches, namely Luja in continence and Heylo in ostomy, resulting in a slower growth; 2) Increased competitive intensity from peers;3) Persisting uncertainty and weak consumer sentiment further delaying China recovery; 4) Elevated input costs and wage inflation. Upside Risks - 1)Better-than-expected growth in Interventional Urology driven by a recovery in Bladder Health and share gains in Women's Health, 2) faster uptake in Heylo, leading to stronger growth, 3) Better-than-expected margin recovery driven by faster organic growth.

Valuation Methodology: We value CVC on a two- part DCF, valuing separately the organic earnings streams of Management fees and Performance fees and carried interest. We value the Management fee stream using a WACC of \(9\%\) and the Performance fee and carried interest stream using a WACC of \(13\%\) (reflecting its higher risk compared with Management fee stream). We use terminal growth rates of \(3\%\) for each stream.

Risks which May Impede the Achievement of the Barclays Research Valuation and Price Target: Downside risks include the following: 1) poor performance in an individual vintage damaging future fundraising; 2) regulatory intervention and change; 3) higher global interest rates; 4) failure to complete announced acquisitions; 5) cultural issues from inorganic activity; 6) stock overhang weighing on the share price; 7) tax risks; 8) high competition for investments leading to slower deployment and fundraising; 9) weak exit market conditions reducing realisations.

*This is the closing price referenced in the publication, which may not be the last available closing price at the time of publication.
Historical stock prices and price targets may have been adjusted for stock splits and dividends.

**Valuation** **Methodology:** We value H&M by taking the average of DCF and PE multiple methodologies. For the DCF, we use a WACC of 9.1%, a terminal growth rate of 3.0% and a terminal EBIT margin of 11.0%. The DCF generates a valuation of SEK 125. We apply a multiple of 18.5x to our FY26 EPS estimate, in line with historical levels, generating an implied value of SEK 134.

**Risks** **which** **May** **Impede** **the** **Achievement** **of** **the** **Barclays** **Research** **Valuation** **and** **Price** **Target:** The three key risk factors that we see to our price target for H&M: • A dramatic change in the competitive environment (e.g. a regulatory clampdown on online importer pure-plays or, vice versa, an abandonment of regulatory tightening). • A dramatic swing in freight, USD or cotton prices which would impact gross margin. • Geopolitical events that impact consumer sentiment and global supply chains.

Sustainable Investing Related Research: There is currently no globally accepted framework or definition (legal, regulatory or otherwise) of, nor market consensus as to what constitutes a 'sustainable', 'ESG', 'green', 'climate- friendly' or an equivalent company, investment, strategy or consideration or what precise attributes are required to be eligible to be categorised by such terms. This means there are different ways to evaluate a

company or an investment and so different values may be placed on certain sustainability credentials as well as adverse ESG- related impacts of companies and ESG controversies. The evolving nature of sustainable investing considerations, models and methodologies means it can be challenging to definitively and universally classify a company or investment under a sustainable investing label and there may be areas where such companies and investments could improve or where adverse ESG- related impacts or ESG controversies exist. The evolving nature of sustainable finance related regulations and the development of jurisdiction- specific regulatory criteria also means that there is likely to be a degree of divergence as to the interpretation of such terms in the market. We expect industry guidance, market practice, and regulations in this field to continue to evolve.

Any information, data, image, or other content including from a third party source contained, referred to herein or used for whatsoever purpose by Barclays or a third party ("Information"), in relation to any actual or potential 'ESG', 'sustainable' or equivalent objective, issue, factor or consideration is not intended to be relied upon for ESG or sustainability classification, regulatory regime or industry initiative purposes ("ESG Regimes"), unless otherwise stated. Nothing in these materials, including any images included therein, is intended to convey, suggest or indicate that Barclays considers or represents any product, service, person or body mentioned in these materials as meeting or qualifying for any ESG or sustainability classification, label or similar standards that may exist under ESG Regimes.
